data: A thick rectangular slab of the local breccia di San Marco (a pink/red stone with white veins), broken in the upper right corner. There is a circular round hole in the top surface.

The text is engraved on the upper surface of the stone (a second text on the front face); a large circular hole intrudes into the first visible line of the text, and the stone is broken away on the right side of the upper part, so the original extent of the text is unclear, but there appears to be a vacat after the third visible line

Plain letters of the middle Hellenistic period: Pi has verticals of equal length; sigma has parallel top and bottom strokes; omicron is small and mid-line; epsilon has a short middle stroke; mu has vertical first and last strokes, while the middle point only descends part way; alpha has both broken and straight bar
Recovered during restoration work in the 1950s or 1960s on the campanile of the Chiesa San Nicolo di Bari
Photo J. Prag, courtesy Museo della cultura e delle Arti Figurative Bizantine e Normanne
Museo della cultura e delle Arti Figurative Bizantine e Normanne

A beautiful collection in a converted church, mainly consisting of stray finds from around town. An excellent epigraphic collection and some material from wells excavated when the church was converted. A highlight is a so-called Kotabos stand
Ricerche di antichità e di epigrafia siceliote
Giacomo Manganaro, «Ricerche di antichità e di epigrafia siceliote», Archeologia Classica 17 (1965): 183–210
Luigi Moretti, «Un ginnasio per Agrigento», Rivista di Filologia e di Istruzione Classica 104 (1976): 182–86
La ginnasiarchia nelle "poleis" dell'occidente mediterraneo antico
G. Cordiano, La ginnasiarchia nelle «poleis» dell’occidente mediterraneo antico, Studi e testi di storia antica 7 (Pisa, 1997)
Sikelika: studi di antichità e di epigrafia della Sicilia greca
Giacomo Manganaro, Sikelika: studi di antichità e di epigrafia della Sicilia greca, Biblioteca di QUCC 8 (Pisa, Roma: Istituti Editoriali e Poligrafici internazionali, 1999)
Manganaro, 1965, Ricerche di antichità e di epigrafia siceliote
Cordiano, 1997, La ginnasiarchia nelle "poleis" dell'occidente mediterraneo antico
Manganaro, 1999, Sikelika: studi di antichità e di epigrafia della Sicilia greca
museo della cultura e delle arti figurative bizantine e normanne

Apparatus criticus

  • Text of Manganaro 1999

translation

commentary

One of two inscriptions on this upright stone, broken in its upper right area. The other inscription, on the front face upper left is ISic001412. Cf. IG XIV.369-71 for other evidence of gymnasion in Haluntium. The text of Manganaro is ambitious and requires revision in light of fresh autopsy

A thick rectangular slab of the local breccia di San Marco (a pink/red stone with white veins), broken in the upper right corner. There is a circular round hole in the top surface.

breccia stele 73 58 16 The text is engraved on the upper surface of the stone (a second text on the front face); a large circular hole intrudes into the first visible line of the text, and the stone is broken away on the right side of the upper part, so the original extent of the text is unclear, but there appears to be a vacat after the third visible line chiselled

Plain letters of the middle Hellenistic period: Pi has verticals of equal length; sigma has parallel top and bottom strokes; omicron is small and mid-line; epsilon has a short middle stroke; mu has vertical first and last strokes, while the middle point only descends part way; alpha has both broken and straight bar
